instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01814A: What is 820-01814A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message:
I've been lurking long enough and need to get into the mix.  Thanks for all of the advice before this thread, because it got me here today.

Customer brought in an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.  It's stuck at 5V pulling .225A.  All 4 USB-C ports have been tested; only 3 were functional.

I'm using the schematic for a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.  No spill damage*; this is a super clean board.

Off the bat, UB300 was visibly fried, and components CB3902, RB258, CB313, CB314, CB301, & <RESISTOR>R4808</RESISTOR> all appeared bad or burned with a small amount of what looked like corrosion.*  All of those components were removed.  RB258 & <RESISTOR>R4808</RESISTOR> were replaced with new resistors.

Many 3V3 rails are present, but no 5V rails.  I thought this was beginning to sound like a T2 firmware issue, so I started down that road as well.  Using Apple Configurator 2, I've tried the Actions -> Advanced -> Revive Device option several times with the target machine successfully in DFU mode.  No joy...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>:                         12.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL>:  12.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>:                          3.399V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL>:        3.324V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>:                     3.323V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>:                 3.007V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>:                    3.373V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ACTIVE_READY</SIGNAL>:          1.8V
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO2_OUT</SIGNAL>:                 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PMU_VDD_MAX</SIGNAL>:                   3.368V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>:                     1.104V
PP1V8_SLPS2R_PMUVDDGPIO  1.806
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>:      5.17V

Missing:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_X_SNS</SIGNAL>  (Diode Mode: .605V)  (Ohms to GND: 27.82k)

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_T_USBC</SIGNAL>               (Diode Mode: .504V)  (Ohms to GND: 16.64k)
<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3G3H_EN</SIGNAL>                (Diode Mode: .596V)  (Ohms to GND: 50.4k)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>                      (Diode Mode: .808V)  (Ohms to GND: 88.5k)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>                      (Diode Mode: .806V)  (Ohms to GND: 86.7k)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"No spill damage*; this is a super clean board
----------------------
a small amount of what looked like corrosion"
Corrosion is result of liquid; corroded board cannot be clean, nor super clean...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is incorrect.
SMC doesn't communicate properly with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, nor with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Read more threads about DFU restore (on the forum).
Some people complained that succeded after many tries and different configurations tested.

All 4 USB-C ports have the same behaviour now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message: Thanks, 2info.  3 of 4 USB-C ports still draw .225A @ 5V.  The 4th port doesn't have a replacement <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> yet.  I'll continue with the DFU procedure, but I'm sticking with the Revive option to prevent data loss associated with the Restore process, as it now wipes out OS and user data.  More to follow...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message: I found a reference in the Rossmann Store which states "If a SINGLE <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on the board is defective, NONE OF THE OTHERS WILL WORK!"  So, this might be my problem.  Parts ordered.  Will update when the new IC is installed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message:
Yes, you must fix this problem first.
That's the reason I asked you for.

Be sure to get same C00, B03, whatever code is...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> replaced and the board now pulls 2.885A @ 19.5V.  Trying DFU Mode -> Advanced -> Revive process now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message: After a couple of tries, (and errors), Apple Configurator 2 silently stated that the Apple Controller booted.  I have fan spin, keyboard backlight, and USB mouse has a light, too.  No backlight or image, and no HDMI output using a USB-C dongle.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message:
Booted!  The display works MUCH better when it's plugged in...  Case closed.

As an aside, the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s from the Rossmann Group Store look slightly different, but DO work in this model of Macbook Pro.  Thank you, 2info and Team Rossmann Group!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) 5V @ .225A
threads.message: You're welcome, glad to hear is solved.
